api.core.preprocessing package

Submodules

api.core.preprocessing.initializers module

Contains simple functions for generating arrays with numbers.

class api.core.preprocessing.initializers.NormalInitializer(mu=0, sigma=0, seed=None)[source]

Bases: BaseInitializer

Normal distribution initializer class N(m,σ).

Generates random samples from the normal distribution with mean mu and standard deviation sigma, using sigma*randn(in, out) + mu formula. Specific implementations of this initializer can change these two parameters. Default configuration will generate simple zeros vector.

Parameters:

  • sigma – standard deviation of the normal distribution, defaults to 0

  • mu – float, mean of the normal distribution, defaults to 0

class api.core.preprocessing.initializers.UniformInitializer(low=0, high=0, seed=None)[source]

Bases: BaseInitializer

Uniform distribution initializer class U(low, high).

Generates random samples from the uniform distribution in the range [low, high]. Specific implementations of this initializer can change these two parameters. Default configuration will generate simple zeros vector.

Parameters:

  • low – lower boundary of the output interval, defaults to 0

  • high – upper boundary of the output interval, defaults to 0

api.core.preprocessing.samplers module

Contains objects for data sampling.

api.core.preprocessing.samplers.train_test_split(*arrays, split=0.7, shuffle=False, seed=None)[source]

Split data set into random train and test subset.

Parameters:

  • arrays – arrays to split

  • split – number between 0 and 1, proportion between train and test subsets, defaults to 0.7

  • shuffle – specifies whether to shuffle the data, defaults to False

  • seed – random seed to reproduce random results, defaults to None

Raises:

ValueError – if less than one array is passed to the function

Returns:

partitioned arrays

api.core.preprocessing.scalers module

Contains implementation for data scalers.

class api.core.preprocessing.scalers.BaseScaler[source]

Bases: object

Base scaler class.

abstract fit(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Get scaler parameters from data sample.

fit_transform(sample)[source]

Combine fit and transform methods.

abstract transform(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Transform data using scaler parameters.

class api.core.preprocessing.scalers.MinMaxScaler(feature_range=(0, 1), sample_min=None, sample_max=None)[source]

Bases: BaseScaler

Transform features by scaling each feature to a given range.

The scaled x is given by (high and low values are taken from the feature range):

std = (x - min) / (max - min)
x_ = std * (high - low) + low

The min and max parameters can be specified manually or using the MinMaxScaler.fit() method. It is also possible to fit and transform at the same time (see BaseScaler.fit_transform() implementation). After the fit method has been explicitly or implicitly called, the sample info (min and max) are saved and can be applied to another sample (using bare transform() method).

>>> data = [[0, 1], [1, 0], [1, 1], [0, 0]]
>>> mms = MinMaxScaler()
>>> mms.fit(data)
MinMaxScaler()
>>> print(mms.min_)
[0 0]
>>> print(mms.max_)
[1 1]
>>> mms.transform(data)
array([[0., 1.],
       [1., 0.],
       [1., 1.],
       [0., 0.]])
Parameters:

  • feature_range – the range to which the data is to be scaled, defaults to (0, 1)

  • sample_min – sample minimum (axis=0)

  • sample_max – sample maximum (axis=0)

fit(sample)[source]

Get scaler parameters from data sample.

transform(sample)[source]

Transform data using scaler parameters.

class api.core.preprocessing.scalers.StandardScaler(mu=None, sigma=None)[source]

Bases: BaseScaler

Standardize data by removing the mean and scaling to unit variance.

The standard x* is calculated as (x - mu) / sigma

The mu and sigma parameters can be specified manually or using the StandardScaler.fit() method. It is also possible to fit and transform at the same time (see BaseScaler.fit_transform() implementation). After the fit method has been explicitly or implicitly called, the sample info (mu and sigma) are saved and can be applied to another sample (using bare transform() method).

>>> data = [[0, 1], [1, 0], [1, 1], [0, 0]]
>>> sc = StandardScaler()
>>> sc.fit(data)
StandardScaler()
>>> print(sc.mu)
[0.5 0.5]
>>> print(sc.sigma)
[0.5 0.5]
>>> sc.transform(data)
array([[-1.,  1.],
       [ 1., -1.],
       [ 1.,  1.],
       [-1., -1.]])
Parameters:

  • mu – mean of the sample

  • sigma – standard deviation of the sample

fit(sample)[source]

Get scaler parameters from data sample.

transform(sample)[source]

Transform data using scaler parameters.

Module contents

Preprocessing root package.

Contains following modules:

  • initializers: contains implementations of array generators

  • samplers: contains functions for sampling data

  • scalers: contains functions for data standardization
